content: The Act is titled the "National Gambling Impact Study Commission Act" and includes findings related to gambling. The Congress finds that the growth of gambling, including electronic and online forms, could impact federal matters. Questions have been raised about the social and economic effects of gambling, prompting the need for a comprehensive study by a federal commission. A federal commission conducted a comprehensive study on the social and economic impacts of gambling in the United States. The National Gambling Impact Study Commission was established by the federal government to study the effects of gambling in the United States. The National Gambling Impact Study Commission, established by the federal government, consists of 9 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, and Majority Leader of the Senate. Members must have knowledge or expertise in the subject matter. The National Gambling Impact Study Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, and Majority Leader of the Senate. Members must have knowledge or expertise in the subject matter and can be from various sectors. Consultation is required among the appointing authorities to ensure fair representation of different viewpoints. The President, Speaker of the House, and Majority Leader of the Senate appoint members to the National Gambling Impact Study Commission. Any vacancies are filled within 60 days. The appointing authorities jointly designate a Chairman, with disagreements resolved by majority vote. The National Gambling Impact Study Commission members are appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, and Majority Leader of the Senate. The Chairman is designated within 15 days of the last member's appointment. Meetings are called by the Chairman, with the initial meeting held within 30 days of the last member's appointment or when funds are available. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for conducting business. The Commission members each have one vote of equal weight. They can establish rules for their business by majority vote, as long as they align with the Act and other laws. The Commission is responsible for carrying out its duties as outlined in the Act. The Commission is tasked with conducting a study on the social and economic impacts of gambling in the United States, including its effects on governments, communities, and social institutions. This study will review existing policies and practices at all levels of government regarding the legalization or prohibition of gambling. The curr_chunk provides an assessment of the impacts of gambling, including its relationship with crime, pathological gambling, economic effects, revenue generation for governments, and the role of advertising. The curr_chunk discusses revenue sources for governments from gambling by electronic means, including interstate and international effects. The Commission is required to submit a comprehensive report to the President, Congress, State Governors, and Native American tribal governments within 2 years of its first meeting. The report will include findings, conclusions, recommendations, and summaries of reports from other commissions. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 5. The Commission may hold hearings, administer oaths, take testimony, and receive evidence to carry out its duties. Witnesses appearing before the Commission shall be paid fees as per the law. If a person fails to provide requested information, the Commission can subpoena necessary documents or data. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas for necessary documents or data, including interrogatories to understand the materials obtained. Witnesses may be required to provide information through sworn depositions or written answers. Each person submitting materials must certify their authenticity and completeness, with false statements subject to penalties under section 1001 of title 18, United States Code. Subpoenas issued by the Commission must comply with the requirements of subpoenas issued by a United States district court. Failure to obey a subpoena may result in the Commission seeking an order from a United States district court. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas for necessary documents or data, including interrogatories. Failure to comply may result in the Commission seeking a court order for compliance. The Commission can also obtain information directly from Federal agencies and must keep such information confidential. Information obtained by the Commission must be kept confidential and can only be disclosed to Commission employees, individuals under contract with the Commission, upon court order, or when publicly released in a non-identifying manner. SEC. 6. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission will be compensated based on the annual rate of basic pay for Level IV of the Executive Schedule. Officers or employees of the United States serving on the Commission will not receive additional compensation. Travel expenses, including per diem, will be provided to Commission members. The Chairman of the Commission may appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. The executive director's compensation should not exceed Level V of the Executive Schedule. Other personnel's compensation will be determined by the Chairman. The Chairman of the Commission has the authority to appoint personnel and set their compensation without following civil service laws. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, and the Chairman can procure temporary services as needed. The Chairman of the Commission can appoint personnel and set their compensation without following civil service laws. Services can be procured under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code, at rates not to exceed the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay prescribed for Level V of the Executive Schedule. SEC. 7. CONTRACTS FOR RESEARCH. The Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations will review and catalog all gambling laws in the US and assist in conducting studies for the Commission. A report detailing the results will be submitted to the Commission. The National Research Council will assist the Commission in conducting studies required by the contract, submitting a report detailing the results within 15 months. The Commission can enter contracts with other organizations for necessary research to fulfill its duties under section 4. SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines "gambling" as any form of wagering conducted in various locations under US jurisdiction, including casino games, sports betting, lotteries, and charitable gaming activities. It also defines "Native American tribal government" as an Indian tribe as per the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act of 1988, and "State" as each US state, the District of Columbia, and the Commonwealth. The Act includes the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and the Northern Mariana Islands. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums authorized for Commission, Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations, and National Academy of Sciences. No payment without advance appropriation. Sums remain available until expended. SEC. 10. TERMINATION OF THE COMMISSION. Commission terminates 60 days after report submission.
